segments.content: , the mab's primordial mass had to have been severely depleted at the earliest stages of the solar system history .the story is much simpler if the primordial mab was partially or fully devoid of material initially . we would like to account for both collisional and dynamical evolution (and depletion) in a self-consistent way .

primordial mab sfd may not necessarily be the same as that from the end of the gas disk phase . we do not consider pebble accretion due to the distinction in the forming regions of s-and c-complex planetesimals that we adopted .the exact time and radial distance of jupiter's formation is unknown .

segments.header: MAB, DATASET, AND COMPARISON WITH MPC
segments.content: b during subsequent 4.5 gyr of solar system evolution to account for loss due to chaotic diffusion of long-term unstable orbits .the row labeled d18 d f ac in tableshows what the depletion factor is in each of those mab sub-regions from .

ds to the conclusion that the late formed s-type component of the sfd would only be affected by depletion via giant planet instability, i.e.therefore, we can safely assume that the overall evolved sds from figurewould not change . this is reasonable approximation if we consider that the giant Planet instability has to happen anytime within 100 myr after gas disk dispersal .
primary goal of our work was to determine the maximum possible total mass that could have existed in the primordial mab region . the current mab total mass is tiny (510 -4 m  ; demeo & carry 2014)
